The fix: %username%\appdata\local\WKND\saved\config\WindowsNoEditor\Engine.ini, and add this string of code:
[/Script/Engine.Engine]
DisplayGamma=3.5

Feel free to change that 3.5 into something higher or lower to suit your particular taste.

review_title: Excellent VR entry for the SW franchise

Fun : - )
Pros: Incredible to live the SW universe in VR.
Cons: The game is more like an interactive story, so don't expect to shoot blasters, fly, or anythign like that. You do wield a lightsaber though. 

Story : - )
Pros: You get to see a backstory on Vader's life.
Cons: It can get confusing for those that not follow the SW lore, quite possibly stories that can be forgotten.

Audio : - D
Pros: Amazing, expect no less than original SW tracks and audio directlly from ILM. 
Cons: None

Visuals :- D
Pros: Great visuals, details, and effects for every environment, it does feel like you are there. 
Cons: Lightsaber animations can look a bit off at times. Also on PCVR the gamma display is extremely dark as opposed to its mobile counterpart..

Gameplay : - |
Pros: VR mechanics are for the most part very good, wished Devs could've added more interaction all around. 
Cons: Climbing is overrated and it seems to be counter productive, other interactions could've been added other than a lot of climbing.  If I want to climb that much I'd just get 'The Climb'.

Replay Value : - |
Pros: The Dojo is exciting at first but then it becomes repetitive, nonetheless is a great experience to have fun with a lightsaber in a 360 degree of combat, and a good way to get friends into VR. 
Cons:  The game/story itself is very short, the Dojo becomes repetitive quickly, it is pretty much a quick visit just to get your lightsaber fix.

The combat sections are essentially 'arcade machine' style. There's no stick locomotion during these segments and that caused me to have to rely more on actually walking, which is difficult in a smaller apartment. This means unless you have a large room to play, I can't imagine there being good movement during combat. I can't speak for if the enemies might follow you as I had to stand still and try to use my small space to lean my avatar in the space to fight back.

As far as combat goes within the story segment, there's 3 fight sections and one of them is less of a fight. One against a Imperial Droid, one where you defend yourself against storm troopers and one where you fight anchient droids. The Droids all used the same pattern of attacks and became easy to read because of this, the main difficulty was once again movement. 

As mentioned, there are positives and I don't want this review keeping Star Wars fans who want a 'in your face' story telling experience away. Looking into Vaders lenses as he towered above you was spine chilling, seeing Mustafar below your ship as you come out of hyperspace and a Star Destroyer above was seriously cool... but for gamers stay away

[SPOILERS]
CONS:
--I was able to complete the entire story in less than 1 hour. That's not even the value of a single movie ticket.
--When your head clips into a wall, it blacks you out and displays a blue icon indicating you should stop clipping. Half-Life: Alyx handles this much better by gradually fading your vision out and making it orange colored. In this case, you just go dark for no apparent reason. Very immersion-breaking.
--There is NO MOVEMENT while fighting with the LIGHT SABER!! WHAT?? You literally have to stand in place the entire time. What a waste of potential! All battle sequences take place with you in a fixed position. F**king LAME.
--There is no realism when using the light saber. Nothing is cut in half or melted the way it should be (with the one minor exeception of the small orbs that float around and shoot lasers). If I slice a robot, it should be sliced in half. If I slice anything in the game world, it should be sliced in half. Extremely disappointed.
--The VR interaction with your hands and the environment is inconsistent and iffy. You can pick up some objects (like the helmet, which I tried to put on, and it went on! That was cool!), but most times your hands just phase through walls and all objects. No contextual interaction except when the game forces it, which means very little opportunity for creative exploration and game play. You cannot even pick up your light saber in some instances. It literally prevents you from holding it. What? Where is my agency?
--Brutally linear.
--Brutally short.
--When fighting robots with Vader, you cannot move, you have to sit there and wait for robots to swing at you, counter the hits, and THEN you are allowed to strike. Any stikes you do in the meantime or with your own reach or enginuity do not count against the robots. No creativity allowed.

I am a deafie.
 
Fantastic game, but one big flaw for me as a deafie -- there is no closed captioning or subtitles.

A very clever way to do it is the way Red Matter does it -- wrist mounted caption screen or subtitle screen.     This is superior to floating subtitles/captions, which are not realistic/nauseating in VR.

Real-world deaf people already use an app called "Live Transcribe" on android phones to caption real-life.  So this would just be a VR version of real life.  And there could be a backscroll feature if we miss dialogue, and maybe a "screenglow" effect coming from the bottom edge if we aren't lifting our wrists to read captions -- some of us might understand what's going on but only need to glance at captions when we need to.

Oculus Store gets docked a star because it does not have a "Subtitles: Yes/No" field like SteamVR does. I heard through a friend that some group at Gallaudet University (deaf university) is considering a lawsuit to Oculus to humbly request Oculus to make a minor change to Oculus Store (a Subtitles Yes/No checkbox) to get them to at least tell deaf gamers whether a VR game has subtitles or not.

P.S. I am the creator Blur Busters, which is all about high refresh rate displays, virtual reality, and high frame rates -- so we also write media coverage about VR.

The best subtitle systems are the "Republque VR"-style gentle floats, or the "Red Matter"-style wrist mounted pipboy equivalent. While I prefer the pipboy style approach (glance at wrist, backscrollable), 

Disney / Lucasfilm can afford to implement subtitles, so a humble request to please implement subtitles. Please? Even if I get my business to donate 500 for this good accessibility cause?

review_title: Could have been so much better
one_reviews_text:
While I love the concept of this game; I found a few issues with implementation.

-You can't fall.  There is a menu option to turn falling on or off, but even with it on, if you step into empty space nothing happens.
-If you fail you get reset way too close to where you were.  At one point you need to grab someone's hand quickly.... and if you don't no big deal, the massive cliff you are falling off doesn't matter you are 3 steps back after a black screen.
-There are too many "stand here" moments.  The AI isn't smart enough to realise you are in the way and move around you, so you are forced to stand still in specific spots many times to get the cutscene right.  While some of this is expected, in most high end (non-VR) games there are scenes like this, but the AI will politely ask you to get out of it's way, shove you out of it's way, or walk around you.  This could have been implemented for Vader Imortal, but wasn't. (Either of the move you options would involve a slight disorientation, but no more than the existing walking mechanics.)  In a few of these scenes I didn't even want to move close to the AI's path, but I was still held in place and it was immersion breaking.
-When fighting you have to stand in one spot.  This one is a HUGE problem. For the cutscenes it was a bit akward but no harm done.  When fighting a giant robot with a sword I wanted to dodge back, or jump forward to attack.  My physical space has enough room to do this. The game wouldn't let me.
-at one point you have to cut a bunch of stuff that is "in your way"... but I climbed over similar stuff just before that and there was a gap to climb over it... why can't I climb?  Then there was a vertical pipe you are supposed to cut... but it has small platforms to the sides you can shimmy around so why do I need to cut it?

Having said all of this, the game is still worth the price even if it is short as others pointed out.  I just expected more from a highly rated room-scale lightsaber experience.

review_title: as game so so, as theme park movie great
one_reviews_text:
If i'd rate this as a game, it would at best get a B- to C from me. Looked at as traditional game, it would be too short, too often block your free movement, just has no challenge at all in story mode (light saber dojo mode has challenge and is more like a traditional game mode).
But after playing the episodes some, it became clear to me that this is not intended to be a game in the traditional sense at all. This is intended to be a fan fantasy fullfillment theme park experience, and as that, it is pretty great, if not excellent.
Graphics and Audio are in a class of their own, very few VR and non VR games and movies come close to this production quality level.
The story and duration is short for usual game standards, but not too short at all when looked at as cinema movie or theme park film.
Basically it is one cinematic moment after the other, never longer than 3-5 minutes doing the same thing. Like as if they made a checklist of what type of Star Wars big cinematic moments could we all have in there, and then they added them all and put one after the other every few minutes. There is a story, with some a bit cheesy worn out moments, some great moments, but to me since i could not stray far from the path nor have branching story choices and the scenery and tasks change constantly, it felt more like the story is there to have a reason to move you from one great Star Wars set piece to another than a world and story one explores freely.
So yeah, if you're looking for a game with constant free movement, challenge etc (in the main story mode, too, not "just" in lightsaber dojo), then you may be disappointed. If you  want a great Star Wars theme park experience, this is hands down the best thing one can have in that field at home right now and really pretty amazing if one thinks about being able to have a theme park experience on this very high visuals, audio and immersion level at home now.
Extra props for the sidekick droid which adds a lot of charm.

The game is very picky about where you're standing in-game, too. Using the former example, you're walking on a ledge on the outside of a building, and the wall is to your right. Some of the geometry gets in the way, the game is removed from your screen and replaced with an arrow saying to move left. You take a careful step left, and even if you slightly rock back too far to the right as you're adjusting your position, it again removes the game and you see the arrow again.

I wanted so badly to get immersed in Star Wars. Some of the scenery that you could look around was breathtaking. But the pickiness of the game regarding your positioning is overwhelming and while the story experience is only about 45 minutes for most people, I have quit playing twice within 35 minutes of gameplay. It's that infuriating. The issue is so glaring and I cannot think of a better way to ruin immersion than what this game does.

review_title: Better than the movies - best PCVR ever!
one_reviews_text: This is probably the most impressive VR experience ever created, graphics are even better than Lone Echo - and I was starting to give up hope to experience such utterly awesome graphics with all these Quest games appearing lately. This version is NOT ported from the Quest - this is the original and extremely high-end version which was cut down to fit the Quest. The level of polygons are off the charts, and that's why you'll need a high-end cpu to run this game (I'm using an i7 7700K). Vader has so many polygons he simply looks real - he's tall - standing right next to you - as if you were truly there. The movies can't give you such an experence, thus this game/experience is better than the movies ;-) Textures are highly detailed, you're not really going to find better textures anywhere, this is an AAA VR experience. It's short though, but the level of work it must have taken to make this is truly incredible. This is a must-have for the Rifts. Black levels on the CV1 are great, and I didn't notice the SDE, so the Oculus Jedi Masters probably helped the devs to get everything perfect. Forcing super sampling (ss) 2.0 using Oculus Tray Tool made everything look ultra-sharp even structures and buildings more than 100 meters away. But using ss 2.0 was expensive, I got 45 fps on my heavily oc'ed GTX 1080, but it was no big deal - thanks to ASW 2.0. For this experience image quality is way more important than solid 90 fps. 16GB system ram worked OK, I don't think having less than 32GB is a problem. Sound using the CV1 headphones was awesome - like being in a theater. Controls were fine, but this is more like a VR movie than a game. Some tutorials were designed for right-handed persons, and I'm left-handed, but I managed. You get an error when you're too close to walls, which the devs could have done better, but again it's no big deal. All in all - for now - you won't find a better VR experience, even if you're a Trekkie ;-)

So it took forever for me to get this that the second episode came out. And my first impression of this game has left me wondering why the hype? I kept hearing about how cool this was and how excited people were for the next episode that I figured it had to be pretty cool. It was not.

So there's a few cool set pieces in here, and a few cool moments. But that's really about it.

Lets start with the first problem, 45 degree snap turning. Not only that but some of the worst snap turning i've experienced in VR. It doesn't start centered up, and then it continues to just decide where front is every few moments. Then I started noticing the incredibly small bounding box telling me to return to the play area. First off I can't see the play area, and the arrow that supposedly tells me where it is is incorrect. So here I am now standing as stiff as possible trying to stay within this arbitrary accepted zone just so I don't accidentally stick my head through a wall.

Then we got the climbing mechanic. How you get worse than someone's thrown together climbing test in Unity I couldn't tell you, but this sucks.

The AI "companion" is annoying and only serves to be in my way and slow me down to make the experience last longer. And if there is enough space to move around them the game just does not let you.

Then there's the robots you fight at the end of the game where they telegraph their attack but don't actually help you figure out which direction or angle it's gonna go. I'm not actually sure it's possible to fail or die, but it's still frustrating feeling like i'm supposed to kill a certain amount before I can continue and i'm getting hit. You don't want to die, but it feels like you're gonna die.

review_title: Your chance to be IN a Star Wars film!
one_reviews_text: Yes it's quite short but it's superbly well done and, at only £7.99, I'd easily rate this as one of my "must have" VR downloads. From the moment you get to flip those switches, push the throttle forward and jump into hyperspace you know you're in for the full Star Wars experience. As well as the light saber "dojo" (which has fantastic replay value and is exactly what you'd imagine wielding a lightsaber would feel like) what will keep this firmly in my list of installed games is that it's THE perfect experience to show to family and friends when you want to wow them with what VR is like. My wife, who generally dislikes computer games (especially those with any "fighting") absolutely LOVED this, finished it in two sessions, wants to play through the whole thing again and is really excited by the prospect of more episodes to come. The production values of the core story are amazing. Yes, it's short, but its qulity graphics, acting, and writting - beautiful, immersive, and just plain well done. I am nowhere near as much of a SW fan as I used to be, but the feeling of stepping into that universe is very well achieved here. 

Then, there is the lightsaber dojo. When I first played it, I thought it was just a mini game where you blocked the little blaster drones (like the one Luke trains with aboard the Falcon in ANH). Gradually however the rounds get harder and harder with a variety of combat droids piling on. The 'saber feels fantastic, and the mix of defense and attack is very good and can be quite a workout at the higher levels. Easily comparable to the best wave-based games like Space Pirate Trainer. Also, if yu purchase it for Rift, its available to you on Quest as well, as I found out when I logged in to my Oculus account on the Quest at work. 

As opposed to other reviews here, I think its an excellent value. I'd have given it about 3 1/2 to 4 stars for the core game, but throwing in the cross-compatibility and the hours I've sunk into the saber dojo, its an easy 5 for me.

review_title: Wow! This is what VR is made for!
one_reviews_text: Vadar Immortal is a short VR experience, but to someone who has played and owns hundreds of VR experiences (a good chunk through subscription based services) this was something truly incredible!

After being reluctant for 3 years to jump on the VR train, I finally caved and purchased an Oculus Rift S. Being a huge Star Wars fan, I knew this game would be among my first purchases. All I can say is I am blown away. The level of immersion this offers is insane. I have always wanted to be IN the Star Wars universe, and this game provided that for me. I felt like I was at Disney's Galaxy's Edge park, even though I have yet to visit. I love this game and while it is short at about 35-40 minutes, it is worth every penny of the $9.99 price tag. As a story driven game it is a great experience! However if the game can give me more freedom in moving around, or moving around while striking it would make the game even more amazing. In the future if the game provide more exploration opportunity  or combat variety experience(more weapons to choose from) or pvp that would be great.

Unfortunately, the episode ends before getting too far into the story leaving it feeling like a $10 demo. 

The controls are where the game lacks even more in my opinion. First off, the game doesn't have any sort of truly smooth turning that I found. There is an option, but all it does is add in frames where your view snaps between set angles. Also, the "return to world" thing completely breaks immersion. Maybe it would have been better to simply add collision and make the player slide back a little instead of plunging the player into darkness with text on the screen.
I've played pretty much everything VR and this is hands down the most immersive cinematic AAA experience you will find!  Except for Part 2!

review_title: Star Wars feeling with some shortcomings
one_reviews_text:
First of all the visuals, the acting, the style, the animation, the Star Wars feeling is excellent! Light Saber fight is fun. Buuut...

- Faaaaaar too short gameplay (~45 minutes) for the price! More of a demo than a game for sale.

- Very often too dark.

- Blocked movement during cinematic sequences. I prefer a confined space in which I can move like I want instead of being glued to a position.

- I had to play sitting instead of standing. While standing the in-game-head-position was too high (especially in the space ship in the beginning and in the tunnels) (I'm 1.90m tall). I looked down on Darth Vader! :-D  While standing I had to squat to reach the ship controls and I had too often a text overlay that directed me to move back. That really was a nuisance. Compare that to the movement in Lone Echo. And while sitting my arms were too wild for the light saber fight ;-)

- No dialog. The robot constantly talked to me without any option for me to talk back. I waited all the time for the robot to start complaining that I don't answer ;-) Even if dialog has no effect on the gameplay it would feel much more immersive if I could talk at least something back.

Overall it had its fun value but too many shortcomings. I hope for an episode 2 with less glitches and longer gameplay because the Star Wars feeling was there and I want to have more ;-)

Vader Immortal ep. 1 consists of two parts: great, but very short and barely interactive experience and solid light-saber training course. Both are very well made, and together they make this game a must-have experience for any Star Wars fan.

Pros:
+ Light-saber handling is amazing: visuals, sound, controller feedback, parrying mechanics - everything is very satisfying. Light-saber is the perfect weapon for VR melee action: it's almost weightless and can cut through anything, solving both problems with immersion of VR slashers. I really hope they will add online multiplayer arena in next episodes
+ Main campaign is engaging and interesting despite lack of actual gameplay. It is a very promising beginning
+ The music is just perfect for Star Wars game

Cons:
- There are less immersion-breaking ways to stop player from clipping into objects than obnoxious warning screen
- Visuals are surprisingly less impressive than in a very spiritually similar experience Arkham VR. Looks like they were build around Oculus Quest's limitations and PC version didn't get enough polish

review_title: Way to short.    I should have read
one_reviews_text: First know the story for episode one is way to short for the price.  What you're left with is the free dojo to work on your lightsabre skills.    I think this should have been under $10.

Worst I can say about it is that it's a little short, I encountered a bug where Zoey wouldn't release my hand after the climb and required a trip to the menu, and putting the lightsaber tutorial in-universe felt more than a little immersion breaking. In spite of all of that I will be showing it to my friends when they come over! Worth it.

I read through many reviews and was aware that this was painfully short, from what I understood it was 1-2 hours of play.  But it's much shorter than that, I'd say about 20 minutes.  Odd, Oculus shows I played it 7 hours, but I only installed it about 2 hours ago so I'm not sure how that's possible.  At any rate even that 20 minutes is not very good. SPOILER ALERT:  You don't get to fight Darth Vader!  Even though he is figured front and center on the marketing with his light saber out, a clear marketing gimmick to get you excited to fight him, you do no such thing.  The fighting is pretty bad, the mechanics are very bare bones.  You basically block 2-3x to open up the opponent then slash, that's it and it's not even very accurate.  There is also returning gun fire, but it's also so inaccurate you just hope for the best. The last fight was so underwhelming, you fight waves of the exact same robots with the exact same moves with the same barely existent combat mechanics. 

It's a shame because this could have been really good, even as a 1 hour demo.  The graphics are excellent, the immersion is very good.  Although the immersion suffers greatly in those very frequent times when you are frozen in place listening to dialogue or waiting for something to happen.  There are some very cool rudiments of an awesome game here, but they are never realized. 

Look, if  you are ok spending the amount you probably pay for an expensive Starbucks cafe I don't blame you.  It's a very cool demo of VR, it's just a very shoddy "game" and not even a very good tech demo.

It's worth $10 to play the 40 dojo levels, but be aware while this is the least buggy VR game I've ever played, there are a few small bugs with detecting lightsaber blocks in later dojo levels. Still worth it! I just hope the following story episodes are released quickly and a little longer. With 3-6 months between episodes, $10 each, and 30-45mins each it wouldn't be worth buying each episode, but this episode is worth it just for the dojo.

Even though there is no force feedback when clashing a saber with an enemy, the vibrational response and licensed sounds really go along way in provoking the imagination.The animations are nicely done and the melee mechanics are remarkadly solid.

The only time I ever really have "OH COMON!?" moments is an annoying glitch where a droid floating behind an standing enemy buzzez towards you from out of line of sight, flies through the enemy from behind (no collision) and strikes you by surprise.

For all the fun I've had going through the short story and mostly playing the lightsaber dojo (theres plenty of levels to complete, and a worthy challenge), it's definately worth $10. Anyone saying this is too expensive? A take-out can you cost you $10...I mean, come on...

I can't wait to finally use the spare hand with new force mechanics the next episode will hopefully bring. Keep up the good work!

*P.S. Lightsaber throw mechanic please (._.)

Nice switch between cinematics and saberplay. Good enough graphics. There could be some pew pew guns, but the lightsaber fights are well made. Hope to get more chapters, more enemy types, and maybe try to use the force. Doesnt last long, but the price isnt too steep either, so all good.
good game but to short hope ther is episode 2 good work  guys

review_title: This Is The Game You've Been Looking For
one_reviews_text:

 Just the occasional screen stutter, but nothing bothersome.

review_title: Can't snap turn while holding two handed
one_reviews_text:
Snap turn doesn't work while holding two handed.  And even when going back to one handed, it seems to take a couple of turn attempts to actually snap turn again.  I'm using smooth snap, didn't try non-smooth snap.

Also, in the dojo, if I'm on a level and take a couple of hits and want to restart, and go to the menu and choose 'start round' it re-loads the map even if I am on the same map.  Unlike if you fail that map and choose the retry option, it just restarts and doesn't reload the same level.  Have a map check when start round is selected, so it doesn't need to reload the same map please.

Also wouldn't mind the light saber sound effects to be a touch higher.  I know you need to hear where opponents are coming from, but the heat of battle I don't hear it much.  Maybe just the hum even when it's startionary.  The saber almost goes completely silent.  I believe that's intentional, but I think a touch more hum would give it presense.  For example, moving the saber slowly from ear to ear didn't result in much hum.

EDIT: I try to rely on snap/smooth turning when available in games, as I have an injury that makes it difficult to phyiscally turn quickly.  I still end up doing it playing vr, but I try to minimize it where I can.  

Really been enjoying the dojo, and wanted to mention that while the current degrees covered for snap is fine for the single player game, it's not enough for the dojo. As in, one can't turn fast enough using snap to face an enemy that's not facing them.   A way to set 45 degrees or in this game in particular maybe 90 would be preferable. 

Btw, accessibility is a good reason to include snap/smooth as an option even on a mobile option like the quest.    I've never played the quest version of VI, so I'm not sure if snap options are available.  Oh and another reason is creeky floors.  I get complaints from others in the house with all the moving about late at night.  heh.
I really liked  the  game ani can't wait for episode 2 to come out

Best $10 I ever spent (well, top 10 at least).  As an AVID lightsaber nerd, this was a deeeeply satisfying experience. The story part was amazing, if not short lived, but the lightsaber training is the real game. It was just challenging enough to keep me entertained, but not so much so that I got frustrated. I really loved being able to interact with a Star Wars environment. I think my heart skipped a beat when we went into hyperspace.  I see massive potential for a full-fledged game using this as a platform.  I can imagine a lot of folks are thinking KotR 3, but with the clunky movment style, I'm thinking more Rebel Assault style.

This was an AMAZING game and I had so much fun with it, but it really is too short. I apreciate the creators getting the game out as fast as possible (and adding the lightsaber dojo for more playing) but there is a reason it is only 10 dollars. Still, I would definatly recomend this game, especially to Star Wars fans. Experiencing the galaxy in VR is awesome.
Its fantastic.. Is all I can say.

Let me start by saying I absolutely loved this game and it's easily worth the money.  Definitely get it.  The story is pretty short, but still fun, and given the cost I think it's a great setup for future iterations.  It's a little dark/foggy at times, but I get that it was originally made for the quest (I played it on the Rift S) so that was probably to help with hardware restrictions?  

The lightsaber training dojo is extremely fun, and especially once you get good at it on higher levels you feel like a complete bad@$$ and even get in some mild exercise in the process.  There is only one somewhat significant design flaw that can be pretty frustrating.  Completionists/people who just want all the lightsabers are going to want to 3-star each round, however unfortunately some of the rounds come down to blind luck in order for it to be possible.  You lose a star if you take too long, and sometimes (arguably most of the time on some levels) you just physically do not have enough time to get all 3 stars even if you do everything perfectly.  Either the droids don't attack quickly enough (and you cannot attack them yourself, only counter), or not enough of the floating balls spawn within reach (meaning you have to wait for them to attack).  This can lead to some frustrating levels where you have to run through them multiple times, perfectly each time, in the hopes that random luck will be on your side for the timing. 

Other than that, awesome game.  I'm definitely looking forward to the next one.
It's pretty short (around 30 min) but the experience is really cool. Every Star Wars fan would totally enjoy it. We need longer games like this !.

review_title: Fun and pretty game, but misleading
one_reviews_text:
All of the advertising for this game touts "You will need the Force to survive the journey ahead." This messaging implies that the gamer will literally receive the 'Force' during the game (in fact, it states that in order to beat the game, you will need the force). Be aware, this is not true (and fairly misleading advertising). If you do decide to buy this game, understand that it is nothing more than a tell-tale VR story that lasts under 1 hr, but includes a wave shooter-like mode. The wave shooter-like mode is actually the meat of the game. It's what makes this game amazing, fun to play, and keeps you coming back. 

But let's get real, this is $10. It's not exactly COD pricing and doesn't claim to be anything close to the depth of a triple A game. You get what you pay for, but in this case, you get lots more.

I'm sure this is something you could get used to, but in a short game it just makes the last battle an awkward onslaught of not knowing who or what is attacking me. After all the glowing reviews everywhere I did pick this one up and promptly forgot about it until today. I suddenly remembered I bought it so I might as well try it out. 

Well. It's not exactly... bad? But it's not exactly near what I imagined after reading and hearing all those reviews. Because actually playing it left me kind of underwhelmed. 

The graphics and sound are better than average, yes. And it's fun to hear the real actors voice the characters. But that's about it really on the positives.

I was constantly getting a notice about "move head inside the world". Sometimes at very confusing spots, like when I was fending off some storm-troopers while standing on a flying platform. No walls around and my feet were planted firmly in the middle of my playspace. And when I wasn't getting that annoyance, I was standing still. Waiting for the next thing to trigger. Waiting. Not doing or experiencing anything of interest. just waiting for the animation to catch up. Then I got a light-saber. And I thought. Wow. Now I might get to do stuff. No. Not really. At action scenes I am stuck at one point flailing the saber around fighting predictable enemies that telegraph moves from miles away. So I put my saber at the intended spot and just wait... again. Even in action scenes I wait. And then the final fight occurs and it's the worst one of all. Just wait. Parry left. Parry right. Do some damage. Rince and repeat. No progress is shown until *SPOILER* steps in and does my job for me. Great feeling of accomplishment I was left there.

So, if invisible walls, waiting, predictable quick-time-events and waiting and a few somewhat interesting settings, and waiting are your thing, then you may love it. Me? I just wanted to get it over with...

review_title: Smooth turn broken and too short but fun

A very well polished "STAR WARS Experience" that lets you live out your fantasy of being in the Star Wars universe. I look forward to the next chapters (I hope the next chapter will let me use blasters). As for replayability, other than the lightsaber dojo mini-game (which is really fun BTW), only the most die-hard Star Wars fan will probably want to repeat the experience (personally I'll probably revisit this from time-to-time when the mood strikes me because it is really cool). But otherwise it's really a must have for those who are Star Wars fans and are interested in a short story (I saw the original in the movie theaters!).  I think I can see where it's going and I would be interested in more episodes; there will come a time in this episode where you understand what may be happening ;)

I gave it four stars since it's a pretty short experience you get.  Do I see five star potential with it?  I think so, but we really need more story and much more game play.

Story: 5

review_title: That's the SW game you were looking for!
one_reviews_text: " Impressive. Most impressive. " We have waited a very long time since Trials of Tatooine came out years ago, and IMO here we are with one of the best SW game of all time. Thank you very much developers, that you managed to create such an accurate environment, such a good lightsaber "feel". The story is very interesting, short (40-50 min. tops), but it's just episode 1, we are going to have 2 more. I've spent 2 hours in the dojo the first time i run the game (if you do it correctly, you are going to sweat...), it's also fun, it offers collectable lightsaber skins and crystals. When you play the dojo, toss away one of your controllers somewhere else in the room, and play with just the dominant one and grab that lightsaber in any style you want, and fight however you want. A series with large potential, though at present in this episode at least constricted by certain elements.

To start off, the immersive feeling is largely there. From the first scene to the descent on the smaller vessel, there is that familiar VR immersion we've come to love in great titles. Certainly helped by the impressive figure of Vader and the Admiral. However, certain scenes are ruined by unconvincing background 2D images, killing part of the immersion (largely the outdoors scenery). Second of all there's frequent instances where movement controls are taken away from the player and too often I somehow seemed to collide with the terrain and get the 'return the the world' bluescreen, even when simply trying to cross a 10cm gap, the same path the droid took before me.

Then there's the lightsaber scenes. Starting off well with the first opponent, although a little stiff and requiring a decent amount of whacking, it's a decent fight to be expected from an introduction to fighting in a new VR title. The second fight with the blasters had me smiling more and was a decent amount of fun. Unfortunately toward the end of this title, the fun in fighting largely fell apart and came about the stiff -no controls movement allowed- with very elaborate predictable patterns that became more of a nuisance and had me wishing to get the scene over with after the 4th or 5th wave, than to have it continue.  Maybe this approach was opted for to make the fights easier and accessible to a larger audience and children. 
More freedom in at least movement control, variation and perhaps a way to increase the difficulty through reduced reaction times and getting rid of some of these elaborate patterns, would go a long way in making the fights not so stiff and more enjoyable.
The sudden ending following those waves caught me a bit off guard, though obviously priced accordingly and with the dojo mode a good value for the money.

All in all a decent title with some future needed improvements.

review_title: Quite Intersting, but not without flaws
one_reviews_text:
It is quite an interesting game, the first story based I played on VR. Firstly it is too short, I would have expected like twice the play time for 10 Euros. 

Also there are some mechanical and gameplay flaws:
- Give the player more freedom, let him teleport around at free will (inside the current playable area). Also let him kill his companions (with the lightsaber) and just do a restart from the last seconds. Let him interact with more random stuff, that he can throw etc.
- The lightsaber blocking feels sometimes a bit strange, I feel that detected blocks should not have worked and the other way around.
- The probably biggest problem was the "Move back into the world" error, I often got it when I was pretty sure I didn not leave the world. Also I took me some experimentation to get what it ment at all. An implementation like in Budget Cuts would have been better, there you see a colorless grid of the world, it helps to understand where you're stuck in.
- All in all the game was too dark, maybe this was on purpose to hide bad textures or something, but for an VR game it really is cool to see the world around you. 

That despite that much flaws I gave 3 stars shows how much I liked the game concept and also many parts where quite immersive. But there really needs to be some work done to improve it.

In addition to the 30-45 minute single player mission, the game offers a secondary "Light saber Dojo" in which you wield your light saber to attack and defend yourself from wave after wave of droid robots, 120 levels total. Initially you face off against waves of blaster-equipped flying droids (see Marksman-H combat remote). Each level their strength and numbers increase with new droids being introduced periodically (3 types in levels 1-16) presenting new challenges fending off different types of attacks simultaneously. 

My thoughts:
Overall this can be fun and dramatically extend the amount of gameplay. New droids keep the gameplay fresh and peak my curiosity so I want to continue to unlock levels and new droids. However there are two big problems that almost completely ruin it for me.

1. LIGHTSABER TOO BRIGHT! CAN'T SEE INCOMING ATTACKS.
As levels become more difficult this becomes a major frustration fending off blaster bolts from different directions especially the close range shots.  Please consider reducing the glow of the saber and possibly increasing the brightness of blaster bolts.

2. DISPLAY GOES BLANK WHEN YOU LEAN TOO FAR WITH NO WARNING.
This is a poor practice for VR game design. It's like sneaking up on someone and putting a blindfold on them. If you must enforce the rule that that the player stays within the hexagon boundary regardless of their playspace size, then please consider an alternative solution. I suggest a simple proximity warning. As you approach the boundary the display glows (some color) then transitions to red when you go out of bounds causing one hit of damage each second until you are back in bounds.
